dfischer.utils

Class CommandInputLineReader

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.io.Reader
      • java.io.BufferedReader
        • dfischer.utils.CommandInputLineReader
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Closeable, java.lang.AutoCloseable, java.lang.Readable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    SMTPUtilityReader, URLImportReader

    public class CommandInputLineReader
extends java.io.BufferedReader
    Read input data and commands line by line in mixed order. Each line can contain either a command or input data. Commands are tagged at the start of the line by a configurable command tag. Empty lines are skipped as well as lines which are tagged by a line comment tag. Lines with input data are spitted into tokens, separated by a set of configurable token characters. If such a token is enfolded by a configurable warp character, the warp characters are automatically removed from the token.

    Default values are:

    1. comment tag: '#' (hash)
    2. command tag: '-' (hyphen)
    3. input token separators: ' \t' (blank) and (tab)
    4. input token wrap char = '"' (double quote)
    Input Example: 
     # line comment
- command1 7788 "7890 89798" hello
data1 data2 "data\" 3" "#data 4" # comment of data
-command2 abc # comment of command
    Output Example: 
    Command = 'command1', arg[0] = '7788', arg[1] = '7890 89798', arg[2] = 'hello'
Data: [0] = 'data1', [1] = 'data2', [2] = 'data" 3', [3] = '#data 4'
Command = 'command2', arg[0] = 'abc'

      • getCommand

        public java.lang.String getCommand()
        Return the command of a line. Note: the method isCommandLine() must already have been called for the corresponding line.
        Returns:
        the command of a line, or null the line does not contain a command, or also null if the method isCommandLine() never has been called for the corresponding line.

      • getCommandArgument

        public java.lang.String getCommandArgument(int index)
        Return an argument of a command, selected by its index.
        Parameters:
        index - the index of the argument (0, 1, 2, ..)
        Returns:
        argument of a command, or null if the line contains no command, and also null if the index is out of range.

      • getData

        public java.lang.String[] getData()
        Return the data tokens of a line.

        the data tokens of a line, or null if the line contains a command.
